Hey Guys!
I’m expecting a huge increase of traffic to our website (we’ll move from 30 users at the same time, to maybe 500). Should i be concerned with the server?

nope. HubSpot handles the server stuff completely.

Their server architecture scales well so I wouldn’t expect any issues at all

how did you guys really test it, throw bots at the site like mad?
Ill let Rob explain it but I know was done using apache benchmark

<@U7SL518D6> What type of tests are you trying to accomplish? From your concerns above, it sounds more like you want to make sure that a surge in general traffic isn't going to cause major site slowness issues. The reason I ask.... If you have a lot of custom JS that can be processor intensive, or a lot of AJAX calls to build out the page, etc, then the way to test it is very different. But if you are just using the typical HubSpot functionality (hubdb, widgets, etc), then a basic apache benchmark test will do great (it will tell you how many HTML requests per second the page can handle minus downloading the extra resources like images, etc)

Let me give you both scenarios (just in case i get caught up in a meeting and can't respond quick)....
If you just need to test the general load capabilities, use Apache Benchmark. To do that, use a Mac or Linux and run "ab -r -c 10 -n 30 <http://someurl/>". That translates to "keep going if i see errors, open up 10 concurrent bots and send a total of 30 requests to that url. Keep in mind that if you have 300 concurrent users, that's not the same thing as active concurrent requests. For example, if someone clicks on a page, then spends 60 seconds reading it, in the analytics world, that use is still active/concurrent. But in the load test world, the second i get a response for that page, i'm immediately making another request.
If you need to download all javascript, etc, then you'll want to use JMeter or something like that. If you need help finding documentation on how to install and set that up, let me know.
I’m good on the documentation. appreciate the overview that’s awesome, didn’t know any of this.
anytime. Been doing it for quite a while. Just let me know if you get stuck running any of the tests. AB can get a little finiky when using SSL.
I’ll keep you in mind, I could see contacting you to outsource some of this if we have a client that needs this kinda testing, as it seems like you know a lot about it.
